channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: A Wall Street Law Firm Wants to Define Consequences of Anti-Israel Protests
item.description: Sullivan & Cromwell is requiring job applicants to explain their participation in protests. Critics see the policy as a way to silence speech about the war.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: New Pushback From Netanyahu Narrows Hopes for a Truce in Gaza
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel would not agree to a permanent cease-fire, digging in at a sensitive moment in the negotiations with Hamas.

item.title: A New Orleans rapper must have all his future songs reviewed by the U.S. government
item.description: “Bling Bling” artist almost faced stricter sanctions.

item.title: Trump Presses G.O.P. for Platform Draft That Softens Stance on Abortion
item.description: The document reflects the former president’s ideological grip on his party, outlining the same nationalistic priorities that his campaign website d

item.title: France’s Leftist Coalition Surges, but Deadlock Looms
item.description: The New Popular Front outpaced the far-right National Rally during the second round of voting. But no party secured an absolute majority, leaving France with a hung Parliament.

item.title: Michael Bloomberg’s charity just donated $1 billion to John’s Hopkins University, covering full tuition for most medical students
item.description: The gift will cover full tuition for medical students from families earning less than $300,000.

item.title: A Republican Platform That Could Read Like a Trump Rally
item.description: The former president’s campaign team has packed the 2024 platform committee, which meets in Milwaukee this week, with the MAGA faithful.

item.title: What Happened in France’s Election? 5 Key Takeaways.
item.description: It was a day of big surprises in France, with the left surging unexpectedly, the far right falling far short of expectations and the question of who will be the next prime minister still unclear.

item.title: The House crypto bill could be the answer to America’s regulatory soul-searching. The ball is now in the Senate’s court
item.description: U.S. digital asset ownership jumped from 30% in 2023 to 40% in 2024. Congress must rise to the occasion and pass FIT21.

item.title: Justice Amy Coney Barrett’s Independent Streak Marked Supreme Court Term
item.description: The junior member of the court’s six-justice conservative supermajority often questioned its approach and wrote important dissents joined by liberal justices.

item.title: France Reacts to Runoff Election Results
item.description: The final tally confirms that the left has the most seats in the National Assembly, with the far right third. Now, there’s a scramble to figure out a way forward.

item.title: Postage stamp prices are about to increase for second time this year
item.description: January’s price hike was just the beginning.

item.title: Columbia Removes Three Deans, Saying Texts Touched on ‘Antisemitic Tropes’
item.description: Nemat Shafik, the university president, called the sentiments in the text messages “unacceptable and deeply upsetting.”

item.title: Modi to Meet Putin in Moscow as India Charts Its Own Course
item.description: India is determined to keep its close ties to Russia despite pressure from the West. Russia sees the meeting as a chance to show it still has influential friends.

item.title: NASCAR just unveiled a $1.5 million electric car—with twice the horsepower as its gas-guzzling cars
item.description: But don’t expect to see EVs in races soon.
